Vis a vis supersonic crack, the mach wave trails the bullet in a cone at roughly a 45 degree angle. (see the atached vdeo)
Note there TWO shock waves per bullet, leading and trailing ends of the projectiles. Since they are so close together, the human ear cannot detect the difference, unlike the " Boom-Boom" generated by supersonic military jet aircraft that I flew back in the 60's and 70s. . From the intended target's vantage point, the sound of a miss is generated from BEHIND him or her. As the video shows, reflected shock waves off of ground, buildings, trees, etc make the task of IDing a shooter by the sound of a bullet's crack a daunting task. BTW, the shock wave from a 50 BMG BULLET is so strong, I had to wear hearing protection from the sound of the BULLET while scoring targets at a 1,000 yard competetion. (It's rather like someone held a 1911 up to my ear and pulled the trigger! Seriously. Not kidding. I used that helpfull bit of info to save me and 5 other hunters in Alaska when two huge brown bears decided to have us for breakfast. The big boar (12 tall and 1,500 pounds) was running at us from 500 yards. I put a 650 grain tracer about 4 inches over his washtub sized skull at 186 yards. He grimmaced, closed his eyes, ducked his head, and bared his fangs. He turned tail and was sill running when he cleared the horizon about 5 miles away.

When an expanding blast wave strikes the surface of the earth or any reflective surfave (aka reflective overpressure), it is reflected off the ground to form a second shock wave traveling behind the first. This reflected wave travels faster than the first, or incident, shock wave since it is traveling through air already moving at high speed due to the passage of the incident wave. The reflected blast wave merges with the incident shock wave to form a single wave, known as the Mach Stem. The overpressure at the front of the Mach wave is generally about twice as great as that at the direct blast wave front (Sandia NL). Reflective overpressure is often experienced by any shooter or explosive breacher with experience shooting indoors - walls, floors, ceiling, all act as a reflective surface. Never stand in corners or at the end of a hallway where the reflective overpressure multiplies exponentially...drop you to your knees, headache for days. If you repeated the same test indoors with the same weapon, you would experience first-hand the effects of reflective overpressure. Great video!

I have taken photos of high speed flybys at airshows where you can see these shock waves off various parts (canopy, air intakes, wing) of the aircraft. This is especially visible under high humidity conditions. The speed at which these shock waves begin to form is called critical mach number. Under ideal lighting conditions, I have seen these on top of an airliner's wing in flight. Pretty cool sight but its rare to get the right kind of lighting and background to see the light rays bending through the shock wave. You have to be seated over the wing and look toward the wing tip, roughly aligned with the shockwave. It's there on every flight but rarely noticed or visible.

Regarding the accelerated air surrounding the subsonic bullet, something I think you would find interesting is that while aircraft risk stalling when they go too slow, a similar thing happens if they go too fast. A shockwave forming over a wing as the air reaches the speed of sound disrupts airflow, causing Mach buffet. The speed at which the aircraft flies to achieve supersonic airflow over the wings is called critical Mach number.

Bonus fact, as altitude increases, the difference between stall speed and critical Mach number decreases until they are the same. This is known as coffin corner.

As an airline pilot, we determine our maximum speed by our Critical Mach number. That number is the speed at which you begin to see localized areas of supersonic airflow.

On my current equipment, we can fly at a speed of m.82. At m.83 (theoretically; there is probably a margin of error built in) we begin to see supersonic airflow in localized areas such as antennas, control surfances, etc. This can cause severe buffeting or even mach tuck if the shockwave builds and reaches the right point on the airfoil.

Absolutely fantastic video! However, I'm afraid your schelieren optics setup may has some flaws. If you look at your footages closely, you will notice there're some severe ghosting going on. Almost all of your footages contain two separate but identical schlieren pattern, if your setup is correct, they should overlap. Base on my own experience from playing with schlieren optics, this is probably because your light source, razor blade and your camera are not perfectly aligned with the optical axis of your parabolic mirror. My solution to this problem is to stick the light source on the razor blade(to make them as close to each other as possible), then put them directly in front of the lens. This way the two schlieren pattern will overlap and enhance contract instead of making the footage looks messy.

This one time, of your many great videos, I'll partially disagree.  The shockwaves along the curved bullet body (at subsonic) is because of its shape and how air accelerates over curved shapes, hence how airplanes fly.  "Moving out of the way" is a poor way to describe that effect.  This is why subsonic jets fly in the Mach .85 range as around the nose, top of the wings, and other curved surfaces, the air travels more quickly and that faster flow also has to stay subsonic.  If that was a straight cylinder you would not see the shockwaves.  Also the position of the body shockwaves are at the regions of greatest change of curvature which demonstrates my point.  Regards from a lifelong engineer and pilot.

Aerodynamic physics is very tricky..  we operate in an everyday realm ,,  when things are pushed outside our known physics, it becomes hyperphysics,,,  When you are shooting these bullets the "fast ones",, you are seeing the flow or air adhere back across the bullet skin..  Push that bullet another 5000 feet a second  the physic properties change.. now the cone leaves the bullet skin and becomes a much wider penetration cone..  to the point its nearly vertical to the point of the bullet.   When they were first setting speed records at the Bonneville salt flats with motorcycles  a phenomenon was witnessed..  They could be steered in the conventional way,, turn right to go right but at higher speeds the driver would turn right to go left..  then back to normal again after obtaining another higher speed..  We give ourselves too much credit for our knowledge base,,  we are at the entry level for understanding the physical world and that was good enough to get us to the moon.. think about 500 years from now..

With all respect, i think that your explanation of the cone was a little wrong. There is 2 limits. The first "cone" that is in the front of the bullet is a supersonic wave (the shock), that forms a bow a little distance above the bullet. The true cone in the beggining of the bullet is the sonic wave that you explained with the classics draws. So don't confuse a shock wave in the air produced by the aceleration of the fluid due to the movement of a body(that can happens even in a subsonic object moving, like de dr explained) with the expansion wave of air that is the sound propagating more slow than the bullet. The spheres that forms a cone in the draws is NOT THE SHOCK.

Eventually the shock dicrease and mix with the expansion wave to produce the sonic boom.
I think you should correct this error.

3:35 these circular wave may be the sound of the bullet under “normal” settings. Imagine the air is hitting the stationary bullet’s tip. That is a percussion, and sound will move from that stationary bullet tip in a spherical way, as sound normally travels. But because the bullet is moving faster than the sound of air hitting the tip, the bullet is moving through the circles that are made.
An arc angle can lead you directly to the point in space where that sound was generated, where the bullet moved away from the point of generation faster than what was generated propagated.

The circles behind the bullet (3:48): In the front of the bullet the air is getting supersonic speeds by beeing displaced by the tip. This causes a linear flow around the bullet. But at the back of the bullet, the vacuum created sucks the air around, creating a high pressure-low pressure fluctuation. I think this circles/spheres are little vaccum implosions right behind the bullet. Their shockwave (or vacuumwave) is traveling at the speed of sound, so roughly half of the speed of the bullet.

We had a wind tunnel at College that would do supersonic speeds... using schlieren.
The tests were just like this only the bullet was stationary and the air was moving by it ...
The throat was only like 4x6 inches, and had windows on both side
We had a light on the far side and we would tape paper on the near side and trace the shock angles by hand.
We tried taking pictures of it (film) but most of time they didn't turn out.
We had this huge tank of compressed air - it would run the wind tunnel for about 4-6-8 seconds depending on the Mach number.
The University didn't want us to do to many tests because it would cost to much money for the department and they had a limited budget.
Then we would have to wait like an hour for the tank to refilled before would could do the next test.
This was in the mid 1980's at the University of Utah.
Brings back great memories.

Great footage as always. A few clarifying points (which you may already know):

1) When using the Mach angle to measure the speed, make sure to measure the angle far away from the object. Since a Mach wave is the weak limit of a shock, the shape of the shock will only approach that of a Mach wave once the distance away from the object is several times the characteristic length scale of the object. Think of it as moving far enough away that the object can be treated as a point mass. If you measure too close, your measurement will be influenced by the local curvature of the bow shock.

2) For the subsonic round, what you're observing is indeed a normal shock. However, the object doesn't have to be traveling at transonic speeds for this to happen. The transonic Mach regime is not a rigidly defined range of Mach numbers. The phenomenon you observed is caused by exceeding the critical Mach number. Critical Mach number is the free stream Mach number at which some point in the flow has a local Mach number >= 1. For a slender object like a bullet, this will occur in the 0.8 - 1.2 Mach range, but a more blunt or otherwise oddly shaped object may have a critical Mach number well below 0.8. So the behavior you saw is a function of the free stream Mach number AND the shape of the object.

the speed of sound is not static! it's actually a range called the "sonic regime" so different parts of an object can be breaking the sound barrier at different times while the object as a whole is all going the same speed! it's why the visible cone on a jet moves down the jet as it passes certain speeds (the cone isn't actually the "sound barrier" it's the water vaporizing because of the low pressure pocket created behind the shockwave, it actually happens much lower than the speed of sound)

My Great Grand-father had a little cabin in the woods in Oregon where his son and his wife (along with my father and aunt) lived. There was a dwarf deer that was coming to his apple tree and because my "Pa" didn't want it to breed he decided to shoot it, but it was outside of deer season so he removed one small pane from his window and sat in the kitchen to wait for the deer.

What an awesome video! I saw a fair amount of Schlieren images in my aerodynamics courses but to actually see things in motion is beyond amazing, thank you so much for doing this! Btw, I don't think you can use the $M=1/\sin{\mu}$ for those shock waves - that relation only applies to sound waves (waves of "infinitesimal" change in density, which do not create any entropy), but not shock waves (across which there is finite change in density and entropy is created). To calculate the Mach number of the incoming flow, you need to know the flow turning angle $\theta$ (which you could determine from the bullet tip shape) and the shock angle $\beta$. The formula is then $$\tan{\theta}=\frac{2\cot{\beta}(M^2\sin^2{\beta}-1)}{(\gamma+1)M^2-2(M\sin^2{\beta}-1)}$$, where $M$ is the Mach number of the incoming flow and $\gamma$ the ratio of specific heats (1.4 for air), but the result is most easily read off a diagram. "Anderson, John D.: Modern Compressible Flow" seems to be a good resource.

An excellent video but one question: When you measure the angle of the shock-wave to the trajectory in your first video, you get approximately arctan(5/8) = 32 degrees. The sine of 32degrees is 0.53 and the inverse of 0.53 is 1.8867 which I agree is the Mach number. Assuming the local air temperature and density give the local speed of sound as 343m/s, the speed of the 50cal projectile accounting for error in angle measurement is around 650m/s. Most 50cal projectiles have muzzle velocities of between 850m/s and 930m/s. So what round did you use?

(I'm a bit rusty on this sorta thing so I might be getting some of this a tad wrong but this is how I think I'd go at finding it out)
Using the frame rate and the known length of the bullet you can find the velocity(or having just watched a little further in you could just use the mach angle to find it), you'd need to know how far the gun is away from the spot being filmed and use the velocity to find when it was fired then divide that by the speed of sound to get how long it would take the shock wave from the muzzle to reach the frame, subtract the time that you got from plugging in the velocity of the bullet and check if the shock wave appears around that time after the bullet enters frame.
You should also be able to do generally the same thing to find out how far the surfaces the supersonic shock waves are bouncing off. We know they'd be going the speed of sound so we just need to time how long it takes for the shock wave to exit at one point to when one of them reenters at that same point, then just multiply by the speed of sound.

I’m a Masters student at TU Braunschweig doing Computational Aerodynamics.
From what I studied, I think the other 2 shocks are not exactly shock waves. It can be explained by so called “Riemann Problem”..
When there is a supersonic flow, there are 3 things happening. In the beginning, there is the shockwave, where there is a sudden change(decrease) in Pressure and velocity and density. It is followed by Contact discontinuity wave, where there is a sudden change in the density. It is followed finally by Expansion wave . It’s weaker than the first 2 waves. Here the pressure and velocity gradually changes back to the surrounding condition.

An aircraft flying Mach .8-1.2 has reached critical Mach. Meaning that even though the aircraft isn’t flying super sonic certain areas on the aircraft are experiencing super sonic airflow due to the acceleration of air around air foils which is a direct result of producing lift. Hypothesis: The circles appearing at regular intervals behind the supersonic shockwave is the shock caused by the flow of air collapsing behind the bullet. The length of the air vacuum tail created by the bullet is controlled as a function of the bullet's shape and velocity. Additionally, the velocity may have some effect on the distribution of air density, causing an observable resonant frequency for the observed phenomena. Bullet rotation may or may not play a part in the phenomena, and should be also explored.

I was just thinking about the circles diagram to demonstrate the shockwaves of the object, and it got me thinking: when you make a disturbance in anything it will make rings (e.g taping the surface of water) the bullet is going so fast that it is causing a disturbance in the air as it goes on to make another disturbance in the air. For example a new 'circle' will develop at the same speed as the rest, before hand, making the size a constant to the time it takes. Using a number of the new disturbances shows an angle and that can tell you the speed.

That is a rough explanation of my theory but I hope it makes sense.

Regarding the later shock waves Destin mentions starting at about 1:41 in the video: So I did a little math and made some guesses. I assumed the bullet went in front of the center of the mirror, and the center of the mirror was 8 inches off the table and 54 inches off the floor. I also assumed the bullet was traveling at 2800 feet per second. Lastly, I very roughly calculated the angle of the shock wave at 30 degrees. (I later remembered that Destin showed an angle in the video of 28.85 - but I'm too lazy to redo the math.) Crunching the numbers, I think a reflection off the table would come about .00046 seconds after the bullet, and a reflection off the floor would be at about .0054 seconds. That's measuring from the time the bullet crosses a point in it's path to the time the reflection crosses the same point.

It would be really cool if Destin could look back at the original video and see how far apart the various shock waves are to see if my very rough figures are anywhere close.

The fact that the SUBSONIC bullet produced shock (Mach) waves at its side is the reason why commercial subsonic aircraft do not get too close to the speed of sound. If they did: 1. There would be supersonic flow at the top of the wing and along the fuselage. 2. The shock wave would increase friction. 3. The airflow would become turbulent around the shock wave, resulting in intolerable vibration.

Then how do supersonic aircraft get around this?
1. They still cause shock waves, but they are DESIGNED so that the flow does not separate from the wing at supersonic speed.
2. They have engines powerful enough to overcome the added friction.
3. They are designed to suppress the turbulence and deal with the turbulence that they cannot suppress to minimize vibration.

What you saw on the sub-sonic round is what I believe is called a trans-sonic shock wave. Some of the  WWII aircraft experienced this especially when in a nose dive. The trans-sonic shock wave actually took air off of the control flaps rendering them useless and made it near impossible to pull out of a dive.  It caused some planes to crash and the designers made serious modifications on the dive bombers to compensate.

Good video, but I am going to go way out of my league and question your findings on the subsonic bullet. Depending on your serious friend's rifle it probably has a rifle twist rate of anywhere from 1:7 to 1:8 so every 7 or 8 inches that bullet will do a full rotation. Bullets on the outside, especially if they have been fired (they will have rifling imprinted on the side of the bullet at the very least), are far from smooth. Here is where it becomes pure conjecture, would that rate of spinning cause a small sonic disruption. In theory if that bullet was traveling at the rate of 1000 feet per second the pullet would make a complete rotation every .04 seconds for a total 1714 (rounded down) rotations per second or 102,840 rotations per minute. If we use the  n • 2πr formula where n = the RPM we should be able to get the velocity 102,840(2 X 3.14 X .154) = 99,458.6 feet per minute which is 1657.6 feet per second which is above the speed of sound. Now I have not taken into consideration drag or loss of velocity for any reason and on top of that I have failed every math class i have taken, but could that account for what you are seeing?

Perfect opportunity to go into why flat base bullets are less efficient than boat tail bullets....but a wasted moment. Boat tails fly more cleanly through the air with less wake turbulence than flat tails. This gives them additional range. The.  .30-03  cartridge was developed for the m1903 springfield rifle. The cartridge had a lot of faults - Round nose, flat tail, and 220 grain weight. The high pressure powder behind the heavy bullet created chamber throat erosion. So they went back and redesigned it using features the Europeans had adopted. They put a spire nose on it, reduced its weight, and gave it a boattail. This new .30 cartridge was adopted in 1906 and became known as the .30-06. It became a premier cartridge in the US. That boattail and nearly 3000 fps velocity made it shoot flatter than other rounds of the period. The WWII ammo for the M1 garand was a derivative of the .30-06. Same dimensions but with a 150 grn. flat base bullet and less powder to lower operating pressure in the garand. It was called M2 ball ammo. But stocks of real .30-06 were still being made for the marine corps and for use by snipers using the m1903 springfield. The boattail and and heavier bullet could make a bullet  reach out and touch the enemy. There's stories of regular GIs using standard .30-06 in their garands for better accuracy. The round of choice was the armor piercing variety. The steel core evidently caused it to gyroscopically precess less than lead core, so has been alleged.

I have myself been studying near speed of sound flows over airplane wings, like what we saw with the slow bullet.
The acceleration of the air around the wing causes it to move faster, but by setting the wing at an angle, the air travels down the length of the wing to extend the time it uses to get over the wing and accelerating the air at an angle, so the extra speed is split up in two vectors. All this is to reduce the speedup of air parallel to the direction of flight.
When the air then reaches the tip of the wing, we then place the winglets, or the tips of the wings, to reduce the turbulence that the air pushed outwards creates. This causes a vortex, or the swirl of air around the tips of wings, reducing drag.

Really cool physics, very simplified in my explanations and even more advanced, but fun, when you get to supersonic flight. However, that briefly explains why commercial airplanes have wings at an angle and some slower propeller planes have straight wings.

Would love to see a video of that if that ever becomes possible!

Hey Destin, if you want to improve your setup: the light travels through the area of interest twice, on its way to the mirror, and when it travels back to the camera. Because of the small offset this puts two schlieren inages on top of each other, with an offset. You can see in your image that everything is double. You can prevent that by having a larger angle between the two paths of the beam (and don't shoot through both of them). I hope this message reaches you.

That Normal Shock is one of the reasons that historical aircraft had issues when they started approaching the speed of sound. That shock wave (non-symmetrical above and below) would start interacting with the control surfaces of the aircraft, causing instability. Getting past that transsonic zone was hard and dangerous back then.

At MIT they offer a class 6.163 called strobe photography. My group for the class did schlieren imagining as our final project and we validated the speed of various bullets using the mach angles as you've described. One other cool thing we did was observe a bullet going from supersonic to subsonic through different refraction index mediums. We created a 4 sided clear sided box with plastic wrap on the two open sides and then rigged a hair dryer to heat up the air inside the box. We positioned the camera such that we could get imaging of the bullet before, during, and after it was in the box. As you know, heating or cooling air changes it's index of refraction. We were able to heat the air in the box enough that a supersonic bullet became subsonic when it entered the box and supersonic again when it exited! The imagery was super cool, and the observation of something we expected was also a very neat experience. Thanks for making the video, I look forward to other projects you get up to with schlieren!!

Howdy. The circles you see are probably the same you hear (the "zip" sound) when a bullet passes by (ignoring the initial blast and the shock you would hear from a supersonic one). Sound waves. Put a powerful speaker in front of your mirror and you should see those too.
Also, if you want to check where reflections are coming from, simply time them and multiply them by the speed of sound. You may need a factor of 0.5 if it is a reflection (time to go and return), or not if it is from the nozzle. I do this all the time in my work doing CFD.

"Normal flow" - AKA supersonic airflow over a subsonic projectile - I learned that in my Aerospace Engineering courses 20 years ago. That's one of the main reasons commercial airliners travel at about 0.8 Mach, rather than much closer to Mach 1 - even at 0.85 Mach, a 747 has portions of the fuselage/wings/tail that have supersonic airflow. And airflow right at supersonic speeds has a LOT of drag. So the preferred cruising speed is the maximum speed where there is minimal supersonic flow.

That's why average airliner speeds have actually gone DOWN since the 747. To minimize this supersonic flow. A 747 CAN achieve speeds of 0.95 Mach, but it becomes VERY inefficient at those speeds. That 10% Mach increase in speed can decrease range by 20%.

The ones you shot in this video were close to supersonic, just under and I was not that surprised at the first SS long shock wave spike, it is at the point of where the Ogive meets the shoulder of the bullet. It is the transition point of the curve of the tip to the straight sides of the bullet. It is like a wing foil and the air would have to speed up over that part just like a wing on an aircraft. That second long spike shock wave would have to be where the air goes back to subsonic. There are always 2 sonic booms as items break the sound barrier. The first one comes when you cross that point of going faster than sound, the second one comes when you transition back below the speed of sound.

You would make a great teacher @Destin @smartereveryday. I fly airplanes upto .85-.88 mach (never went faster than that). I believe the sub-sonic bullet works the same as an airplane. However, commercial airplanes don't like supersonic airflow over their wings, therefore the wings are swept back to keep the flow sub-sonic. The max speed of an aircraft is Critical Mach Number, if exceeded, the wing will stall because the air becomes supersonic over the wings. Without the sweep back, the airflow over the wings will be supersonic even at sub-sonic speed of the airplane.
Bernoulli's theorem explains the reason why the air speeds up over the wing or a bullet that has an airfoil like desgin.

I've noticed in a lot of slow motion videos that some bullets fly 'crooked'. In this vid the supersonic rounds look 'straight' but you can see it clearly in the subsonic round in this video. Coop is shooting slightly downward towards the target so the bullets fly past the mirror in a ~5 degree downward angle. However, in the subsonic shot the bullet itself is actually pitched up a tad from level with the floor.


Many times you'll actually see videos where the bullet actually pointing downwards, but it doesn't seem to impact the direction of flight that much.


My basic theory on this has been that the bullet is knocked 'crooked' by the muzzle blast, and that most of the aerodynamic forces are concentrated at the very tip so there's little remaining to 'correct' the pitch of the bullet or cause the flight to drift from the slightly varying angles of attack.


If you guys get to shooting again, it would be interesting to see if there is any evidence of yaw in the bullet (maybe by filming from below or via mirror on the floor). If the cant is induced by muzzle blast it would be chaotic and just as likely to point to the side as it is up or down.

Cool video. When we talk about supersonic flow and transonic flow there are shockwaves, and also expansion fans. Expansion Fans are supersonic flow that is expanding, the opposite of the compression of the shockwave.  With the transonic bullet, the air moving around the bullet first is subsonically compressed at the nose of the bullet, and expands as it moves around the bullets body. The expansion fans form first, supersonic expansion. This is followed by the "Wake"  shockwave, a normal shockwave where the supersonic flow is compressed and transitions back to subsonic flow behind the normal shockwave. So,  as and aircraft accelerates through the sound barrier, the Expansion Fans grow followed by the growing normal shockwave of the "Wake" shock and the tail of the aircraft is flying supersonically while there is no "Bow" shockwave and the nose of the aircraft is flying subsonically. The Sound Barrier sneaks up from behind. At Mach=1, the "Wake" shockwave size goes to infinity and the "Bow" "normal" shockwave is formed.

Okay, the circles you see in the image. Here is my hypothesis:

We are looking at a 2D projection of a 3D cone created by spheres of pressure waves. In an ideal fluid where it's equally dense in all locations, you would not see those spheres as easily. However, in air that is constantly moving and fluctuating, as air in an open shop would, we get slight differences in pressure. As the bullet flies through those areas of slightly differing pressure, those differences affect the spheres of pressure that are generated, and they become slightly offset from each other in energy/size/other aspects. This offset becomes clearly visible inside of the cone that the spheres make up. You are seeing the side profile of the spheres that are offset from their neighboring spheres in some way.

Also note, because you placed the razor horizontally, you emphasized vertical differences in photon refraction as opposed to horizontal differences. If you place the razor vertically, you might be able to emphasize the vertical profile of the circles even more because it would be emphasizing horizontal differences in refraction. That's just a guess though.

PS: If you look at the super sonic bullet ( 1:32 ), you also get those funky lines on the side of the bullet. Those funky lines not only appear just as they did on the sub sonic bullet, they are appearing INSIDE an already existing sonic boom and more than that, they are at a sharper angle than the already existing sonic boom. Those are tiny sonic booms within the sonic boom. Why is the angle sharper? My only guess is that the density of the air in the sonic boom (between the front and back ends) actually makes the speed of sound SLOWER inside the sonic boom, hence the angle being sharper on the inside, and bending to match the regular angle as it passes through the density differential to reach the back end of the sonic boom.

Bernoulli's principle explains that an increase in velocity is a decrease in pressure and an increase in pressure is a decrease in velocity. The shape of the subsonic round causes the velocity of the round to be subsonic, but, since the round is still divergent the is air pushed out of the way of the bullet to reduce pressure, increasing the velocity. That is what causes the supersonic peaks of air. The same thing happens to wings on an airplane and a lot of high bypass jet engines like the PW2000 or TF34.

Source: USAF

An interesting thing about transonic flow is that, because of the combined sub and supersonic areas, it makes it difficult to design planes to fly in that region. Most commercial planes moght fligh in a low transonic regime, around 0.8-0.85, but then you don't really find any aircraft in the region above it, until it's maybe the 1.1 or higher Mach range where you start getting the design points of supersonic aircraft. This is because the differences in what the flow does between subsonic and supersonic means whenever you're in that transitioning range you get huge losses, with both extra drag and less efficient propulsion (transonic pinch). As an example of these flow differences is what happens in a diverging nozzle- in subsonic flow, diverging nozzles decelerate the flow. The opposite happens in supersonic flow, where a diverging nozzle section actually accelerates the flow, the complete opposite of subsonic.

Quite a few supersonic aircraft engines use this in whats called a 'con-di nozzle' (converging-diverging). The converging section accelerates subsonic flow until it reaches Mach 1, then (because of the opposite flow effects described above), further acceleration of the flow occurs in the supersonic section in the diverging half of the nozzle

I'm studying aerospace engineering and in this year they taught me that the shockwave that forms in front of an object doesn't need to have the angle of a Mach cone since the reason shockwaves appear is deviating the supersonic flow front me object it is going to encounter. Therefore the angle of the shockwave depends on the speed and the angle of deviation needed. The only way it creates a Mach cone is when the angle is very small, then the angle tends to the one of a Mach cone. I'm saying this because I don't think those speed calculations are too valid, they can approach the real speed but not the most legit thing. I think that the speed calculation is not totally correct. What you did is only valid for dimensionless points moving. For  an actual 3D object as a bullet, the shape itself modifies the angle of the shock waves, depending on the angle of the bullet itself, what it is called the nose cone. If the angle is  big (blunt body) the shock wave detaches front the nose. That's why supersonic airplanes have sharp nose cones. It''s difficult to explain in a comment here. An idea for a following video could be to film bullets in supersonic flight with sharp and blunt noses at the same speed to see the difference in the shock wave angles and how they detach.

Wow! Very cool! This is the same phenomenon that causes Bremsstrahlung radiation! Charged particles moving faster than light in a specific medium (say water or ice) is equivalent to an object moving faster than sound in air! In neutrino detectors (like IceCube), we measure the "Mach angle" of the light cone produced from the radiation and that tells us the speed (energy) of the incident neutrino! Amazing!

Source: Astrophysicist

Desitin, they are not little circles they are spheres. We live in a (for simplicity sake) three dimensional world, the illustrations in your old aerodynamics book only show them as circles because it's easier to illustrate.  Theoretically the bullet lives in a neutral state bubble of air. We all do. When an object moves fast enough to break out of the bubble the sonic boom is the bubble collapsing to try and catch up. People theorize that the speed of light is similar to this and therefore think that either a type of black hole or a flash of light happens if/when you go FTL. Of course, No one really knows what the "light boom" would look like. This similar "bubble of X (in this case sound)" is that famous Bubble Theory you've probably heard of  before.  Conceptually you just videoed inter dimensional travel.

This reminded me of something that my friend did. They were out hunting deer and to avoid a long detour they had to cross some private property that had some livestock on it.
My friend knocked on the property owner's door to ask if they could cross the property.
The owner said it wouldn't be a problem, but he asked my friend to shoot the old donkey that needed to be put down. "But don't shoot the cows! I'm raising them for the State Fair contest that I've won for the last 5 years running."
My friend agreed and went back out to join his friends. He saw the donkey (which was limping badly) and the two prize cows. My friend was a bit of a prankster and though he would play one on his hunting buddies.
My friend was very mild mannered and willful destruction of the properties of others so when he rejoined his friends he said, "They guy said "Go around" and slammed the door in my face." He drew a bead on the donkey and fired, achieving a perfect heart shot, the animal dropped without knowing what hit him.
He expected to see his friends looking at him with their mouths gaping at his out of character behavior when he would explain the deal he made.
What he saw, to his horror was his friends aiming at the cows. Before he could stop them they fired. Unfortunately, their marksmanship was equal to his. The cows died as quickly as the donkey had.
Before commenting, this story is a rather old joke. It didn't happen as far as I know, but there may be some who haven't heard it.

One of the coolest moments of my life was seeing a shockwave coming from a traveling bullet. I was shooting at the range with my dad. I was spotting for him and could see the bullet travel downrange with a shockwave following close behind. I think the reason I could see it happen was the weather was perfect for allowing me to see it with the naked eye. I'm curious if any meteorologist could go into detail on how the shockwave was possible to see. I don't remember much other than it was raining that day, a light drizzle I believe, and maybe had high humidity since it took place in Florida and most rain happen because of high humidity. Wondering if air pressure played a factor.

You were speculating about where the secondary shockwaves were coming from, if they were bouncing off the table or floor or what. You ought to be able to figure that out better than just guesses. You know the time delay between when the bullet passed and when the shockwave appears, and you know the speed of sound. So you should be able to get the distance to whichever surface the waves bounced off of. And with knowledge of the layout of the shop it shouldn't be too difficult to work out.
